com:
Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, weather, etc)
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with basic system apps.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: 
wsreset -i


>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS/Polaris and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/overview-office-deployment-tool

from math import ceil, copysign as cs

def step_pos(pos,step):
    return (pos[0]+step[0],pos[1]+step[1])

def get_dist(knot1,knot2):
    return (knot1[0]-knot2[0],knot1[1]-knot2[1])


def part2(inp):
    dirs = {
        'U':( 0, 1),
        'D':( 0,-1),
        'L':(-1, 0),
        'R':( 1, 0)
    }

    knots = [(0,0) for i in range(10)]
    t_hist = {(0,0)}
    for move in inp.strip().split('\n'):
        dir,dist = move.split()
        for step in range(int(dist)):
            knots[0] = step_pos(knots[0],dirs[dir])
            for knot_ind in range(1,len(knots)):
                dists = get_dist(knots[knot_ind-1],knots[knot_ind])
                if 2 in dists or -2 in dists:
                    knots[knot_ind] = step_pos(knots[knot_ind],(cs(ceil(abs(dists[0])/2),dists[0]),cs(ceil(abs(dists[1])/2),dists[1])))
            t_hist.add(knots[9])
    print(len(t_hist))

whether or not esims are annoying depends entirely on the software support of your phone and the carrier providing the esim data.
It's incredibly fucking convenient for me, because my phone has really good support, and my carrier is esim-first, so I just download the esim from my carrier's site and manage it in my phone settings to choose which esim or physical sim to use for data/calls/backup.
If it's only $10 then I'd recommend just buying a month now and making sure it works well for you.
>which would be enough for gps
Keep in mind that GPS, as a location service, isn't provided by your carrier and should work fine without any sim at all, you just need a data connection to download a map of the surrounding area if you don't already have it saved. Many maps apps can cache a predefined area offline and use GPS without cell service, but you can't use any online route planning if you do that.

com:
Rate this program

 // Import the child_process module
const { exec } = require('child_process');

// Define the command to run
const command = 'pacman -Qu';

// Define the refresh interval in milliseconds
const refreshInterval = 60000;

// Create an object to store the module's state
const state = {
  updates: [],
  interval: null,
  timeout: null
};

// Define the module's update function
const update = () => {
  // Run the pacman command to check for updates
  exec(command, (error, stdout, stderr) => {
    if (error || stderr) {
      // Log the error and return
      console.error(error || stderr);
      return;
    }

    // Parse the output of the pacman command
    const updates = stdout
      .trim()
      .split('\n')
      .map(line => line.split(' ')[0]);

    // Update the module's state with the parsed updates
    state.updates = updates;

    // Notify waybar that the module has updated
    waybar.update();
  });
};

// Define the module's click handler
const onClick = () => {
  // Open the system updates manager
  exec('pamac-manager');
};

// Define the module's render function
const render = () => {
  // Check if there are updates available
  if (state.updates.length === 0) {
    // If there are no updates available, return an empty string
    return '';
  }

  // If there are updates available, return a string with the number of updates
  return `${state.updates.length} updates available`;
};

// Start the refresh interval
state.interval = setInterval(update, refreshInterval);

// Initialize the module
update();

// Export the module's functions
module.exports = {
  update,
  onClick,
  render
};

com:
Gave up on the minimalism meme pill when I realized the Linux kernel is bloat.
>100+mb binary
Lmao.
Of course it's unavoidable, because it's just doing the least it has to do to talk to severely bloated modern hardware.
The computer itself is bloat from end to end and the size of the kernel is just an artifact of this. Too many bus protocols, too many exceptions and edge cases, too many standards, too many redundant pins, too many mysterious controller-internal blackbox behaviors, etc. For fucks sake you literally have a second computer inside your primary computer that does nothing but process a high-level description of the graphics you want and calculate the pixels to stream to your monitor.
The final solution to the bloat question is to:
>write an architecture from scratch
>no-bullshit instruction set and register space whose details are easy enough for a retard to understand
>no memory protection
>no cache
>no hardware parallelism (no multicore, no pipeline)
>only one word size
>uses a custom minimal bus protocol, no usb / pci shit
>no gpu, vram stores the pure pixel buffer and directly streams it to the display with no processing, any graphics processing prior to the pixel stage is done with software rendering
>make the i/o controllers yourself and make them so homogeneous that you only need one universal driver
>write an assembler for your architecture
>write or cross-compile a compiler
>write firmware, bootloader, kernel
>port over your preferred minimal userland software
I don't wanna do all this so i'm just using linux anyway and using whatever software i want because my based minimal dream can't come true as long as i'm using this bloated kernel. I failed bros

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I generally do not connect to web sites from my own machine, aside from a few sites I have some special relationship with. I usually fetch web pages from other sites by sending mail to a program (see https://git.savannah.gnu.org/git/womb/hacks.git) that fetches them, much like wget, and then mails them back to me. Then I look at them using a web browser, unless it is easy to see the text in the HTML page directly. I usually try lynx first, then a graphical browser if the page needs it.

I occasionally also browse unrelated sites using IceCat via Tor. Except for rare cases, I do not identify myself to them. I think that plus Tor plus LibreJS is enough to prevent my browsing from being associated with me. IceCat blocks tracking tags and most fingerprinting methods.

I never run nonfree Javascript on my browser, unless LibreJS finds it to be trivial.

last_replies.com:
>>90203221
Don't use it for anything if you can. Keep it in battery saver mode. Limit or remove apps that run in the background. I get about 5 days out of mine before it hits mid 20%. Then I plug it in that night and adaptive charging slowly charges it overnight. I also keep a small fan blowing across it preventing the phone from getting hot while charging. All this shit makes the phone last about 5 years before the battery gets to the point where how long the charge lasts is noticeably shorter.

sub: Software is actively getting worse, why??
com:
>try to use some website
>everything is hidden, layout is retarded and covered in overlays
>dynamically loaded content randomly pops in moving shit around
>basic fucking features don't work, are impossible to figure out, or are just straight up missing

>using locally installed application
>broken as fuck
>update comes out
>they added telemetry instead of fixing the broken shit

>on android
>forces updates that actively fuck your shit up

Software isn't just stagnating, it's actively getting fucking WORSE. I'm starting to come to terms with the fact that 90% of the reason I even use this website is because it doesn't randomly completely self destruct. Using the modern internet, or just modern software in general has become an exercise in mental anguish. It's not enough that software just gets developed and works, it's like someone has to come along and intentionally fuck things in the ass. My city transit app worked perfectly fine 2/3 years ago: now they've added a bunch of gay "gamification" horseshit to it while the main functionality has degraded to the point where it's more likely to sabotage me than it is to help.

What does it mean for humanity that the increases in productivity that we saw at the dawn of the information age are being destroyed as computers actively become LESS fucking useful? How can we even begin to turn this ship around? It seems that the entirety of the tech world is reaching a kind of critical mass where just using a computer for normal shit is now actually worse than doing without.

I can't shake the feeling that we're actively regressing.

>>90187218
This is due to high level encapsulation: programming languages have gone so far away from the metal that they no longer represent a linear and rational system based upon the natural ordering of data, they are able to be manipulated in a high level and irrational way. High level abstraction was a mistake, instead of making people smarter and more rational in order to deal with low level access to the machine, people have made languages more idiot proof and irrational in order to make it easier for idiots to develop terrible "solutions" to problems. Every issue with modern software is a result of high level abstraction, an archetypal example of this sort of behaviour is with a zoomer programming a discord bot in a slow language like javascript using a library and knowing nothing about networking, instead of just programming a chat server in C with sockets. Programming has been opened to the retards, there's your problem.
